userreviews.userReview: We’d all like to think that we’d do “the right thing” in certain situations, but what would you do if you found an abandoned newborn? That’s exactly what a New York City man had to ask himself when he found an infant on the ACE subway platform. Author, Yona Zeldis McDonough, a Brooklyn native, was so taken by this story that it was the inspiration for this book.Miranda was content in the thought that she may never be a mother. In her mid-thirties and single, the chances weren’t looking too good. But she had a great job and amazing friends. Things definitely could be worse. Her life changed one night when she was heading home from a night out with the girls. Walking through the subway station, she spied the usual sights … people running to catch their train, a homeless person huddling in the corner, but it wasn’t until she saw a little bundle with a foot sticking out that she stopped to take notice. At first, she thought maybe it was a doll, but when the foot moved she knew that she stumbled upon something more than a child’s discarded toy. She found someone’s discarded baby! After turning the baby over to the local police, Miranda couldn’t get the thought of that little baby out of her mind. She went to the court to inquire about the infant and was shocked when she was asked to consider fostering the baby. A bit nervous, what did she know about raising a baby?, she decided to take on the challenge. It didn’t take long for her to fall in love with this child, whom she named Celeste. But when a local paper got wind of the story and asked to do an interview, things got complicated. A man claiming to be the baby’s father surfaced and was looking to claim his child. Heartbroken and confused, Miranda was torn between fighting for the baby that she loved and returning her to the rightful parent.As a foster and adoptive parent, this book spoke volumes to me. I could relate to much of what Miranda was going through with the inner turmoil of loving a child unconditionally, yet knowing that they can be taken from you without question. The joys that a child brings to your life, and the sorrows of the unknown. The author does a brilliant job of bringing out real, raw emotions while making you feel like you’re living the story along with Miranda. A heart-wrenching story about love, family, sacrifices … life! Go out and get this book. You won’t be able to put it down until you hit the last page!

Miranda Berenzweig has good friends, a great job as food editor of a magazine, and is getting over an unfortunate relationship when she finds an abandoned newborn baby on the subway platform. After taking the little girl to the nearest police station, she goes home....hoping the baby will find a loving family. But Miranda worries about her and keeps in touch with the handling of her case. The judge suggests that Miranda become her foster mother and possibly adopt her. But complications arise when the baby's father shows up. This was actually quite interesting. If you like chick lit romantic novels I'm sure you'll love "You Were Meant for Me". But for me it was just too corny! Miranda's emotional maturity must hover around an 8th grade level.

With a sure hand and her customary gift for telling detail, Yona Zeldis McDonough weaves an extraordinary story of treasures lost and found. And what a perfect title! Fate, in the form of an abandoned infant, confronts our heroine at her loneliest hour. What unfolds after this magical beginning is both psychologically astute and a glimpse into the meaning of life. McDonough's poignant and witty novel is as much a love story as it is a tale of redemption; both blessings will linger long after the last page is read.

Review  You know a book is good when you have a reaction.  You Were Meant for Me had me feeling all of those new mommy feelings all over again.I think the characters in this book were amazing.  We have three characters that we follow: Miranda, Evan and Jared.  Each person adds an development in Miranda's life.  Miranda has to decide which friends really support her through everything with finding the newborn.  Miranda has to learn that she has to be strong in order to endure all the problems that come with raising a child.You Were Meant for Me is so much more than learning how to adjust to having a child that is not your own.  It's about love, heartbreak, friendship, loss, and dealing with all the things life throws in your way.  I think through the ups and downs Miranda finds herself.  She learns what she finds important, and how to be comfortable with her actions.

What a great story! A well blended combination of love, happiness, acceptance, loss, sorrow and friendship. Sure some of those may mean similar things, but the situations are different.The story is primarily about Miranda and the baby she finds abandoned at a subway station in NY. It is the end of the line and Miranda is there because she fell asleep and missed her stop. Perhaps that was a good thing. Miranda follows up on the baby and manages to become her foster mother on the road to adoption...much to the chagrin of some of her friends.I loved the story and felt like I was there and part of the story. Not everything was easy for Miranda during this journey, but she is very level headed and knew when she wouldn't win. Bea, Lauren and Courtney round out her friends and they all bring something different to the story. Courtney has more of a personal story line than Lauren or Bea, but she is fairly opposite of Miranda, so that is probably why.Jared, the baby's father, has some life changing experiences and it causes him to grow up faster than maybe he would have liked.And then there is Evan, photographer extraordinaire, and possibly the love of Miranda's life. But is his timing right for a relationship to happen?Overall very enjoyable story

I loved this book! And yes, the cover is what caught my eye ;)This story, although rooted in a sad, true one, turns sweet within a heartbeat through Yona's characters and her smooth writing style.I like the way the author handled all the touchy subjects in this book. Obviously either very close to the author's life or very well researched. Either way, a great read. Very entertaining. Likable, relocatable characters. What touched me most was the honest emotions and situations the characters of YOU WERE MEANT FOR ME went through. I enjoy women's fiction because of the emotional journey and growth of the women in the book. And this book did not disappoint. I actually felt as though some of the story came alive in ways that I didn't feel apparent and being surprised by a book's outcome ranks high in my opinion. Have recommended it far and wide!

AMAZING STORY!I think some of the readers that gave low ratings missed the main feeling that the book was meant to give: compassion and empathy.Miranda has everything: friends, a great job, a good life until she finds a soul that needs her.What transpires the most in this book is what make us human: affection.Miranda starts to worries and soon she becomes a MOMMY.

I really liked this book, it was fast moving and kept me interested the whole time. I wish it was longer to read the continue story of Miranda, Celeste and Evan. I am plan on reading this author's other books.
Loved this book---not the usual Chick-Lit--insightful characters.
http://rochellejewelshapiro.com/you-w...

this book was just ok for me...I didn't find the characters having a great deal of depth. especially Jared who I found very immature and self centered. None of it seemed that realistic and not a huge amount of depth in the story. very predicable.Thirty-five-year-old Miranda is not an impulsive person. She’s been at Domestic Goddess magazine for eight years, she has great friends, and she’s finally moving on after a breakup. Having a baby isn’t even on her radar—until the day she discovers an abandoned newborn on the platform of a Brooklyn subway station. Rushing the little girl to the closest police station, Miranda hopes and prays she’ll be all right and that a loving family will step forward to take her.Yet Miranda can’t seem to get the baby off her mind and keeps coming up with excuses to go check on her, until finally a family court judge asks whether she’d like to be the baby’s foster parent—maybe even adopt her. To her own surprise, Miranda jumps at the chance. But nothing could have prepared her for the ecstasy of new-mother love—or the heartbreak she faces when the baby’s father surfaces....

Thirty-five year old Miranda has her close friends, a great job as a food editor for a popular magazine, and her own apartment. She is just coming off a break-up with a disappointing guy, but she's ok; she just got a promotion at work and she is getting on with her life. All is well.As Miranda makes her way home from a night out with her girlfriends, her life changes. Finding an abandoned newborn on the Brooklyn subway station leads her to unexpected, but oh, so wanted, motherhood. Miranda has never known such happiness, but then the biological father enters the picture. Jared hadn't realized that his unstable girlfriend was telling the truth when she told him she was pregnant; now he has to decide whether to be a stand-up kind of guy and be a father or whether to pretend it all never happened in the first place. He does the "right" thing and heartache begins.The concept of the story was great, but for me, this story just didn't even begin to relate all the pain and all the struggles a foster parent or adoptive parent must go through. Miranda had it fairly easy--she was able to hire a full-time nanny and to get on with her life. She fell immediately into another relationship. Jared came across as, well, just sleazy; even though he did do the "right" thing for his daughter. He, too, had all the comforts in his life that would allow him to hire a nanny and a back-up in order for him to follow his own lifestyle as up and coming realtor with wealthy clients, especially the wealthy, attractive wives.For the characters to have been in their mid-thirties, I found them to "figures on a stick". I never got to really know them and I found their thirty-something behavior to be immature...but maybe I just don't understand the City Life and Successful Singles. I just didn't feel the pain or the struggles that someone who found a baby and wanted to adopt would really go through, or at least what I think they would go through. The book became more about the relationship issues than about the baby. There were a lot of back and forth relationships that clouded the main issue and took up a lot of pages with little substance. It seemed that McDonough was trying too hard to show diversity in characters--a lesbian, up and coming African Americans, an elderly man with Alzheimer's, a middle-eastern nanny, a mentally unstable woman....yes, these are people in our lives; but McDonough didn't trust the reader figure it all out; she was quick to point it out in print that her characters were a diverse mix.In the end, all works out; rather abruptly, but happily. I happily closed the book and then thought that what could have been a really moving story just turned out to be a light, fluffy and not even funny work of chic lit; which I like from time to time, but which just didn't seem fair to this story line.

Originally reviewed at Novel EscapesI finished reading You Were Meant For Me with mixed feelings. While the concept was great (both unusual and interesting) I had a hard time with the pace on occasion and some of the emotional connections throughout. There were so many good things about it though, that on the whole I enjoyed the book.Miranda is still a bit of a mystery to me. Sometimes I felt as if she’d got everything in her life under control: the great position at work where she’s well respected, the adult way she’s handling her father’s dementia and the control she takes when she realises she’d like to foster (and possibly adopt) the baby she discovered. They all showed a woman who knows what she wants and how to go about getting it. My confusion lay with the personal relationships throughout the novel. She has an almost grade-school relationship with her friends which I couldn’t really fathom. I know that no one has everything sorted out but I still would have expected Miranda to have more than one friend (the actress) who had the maturity to help her when she needed it. They didn’t add much of anything to the story except frustration. However the older women (the nanny and the landlady) presented in the novel were both wonderful and I suppose were there to represent the mother figure for Miranda when her friends proved to be unhelpful.I was almost ready to accept Miranda’s new life with baby Celeste and potential partner Evan when we were thrown the curve ball of baby’s biological father Jared turning up. I actually liked his character and his purpose to the plot (potential romantic interest aside) and despite him having some questionable personality traits I found myself understanding him. I think his intentions were good and the author was careful to let us know his relationship with his own mother had been a loving one and that he respected her greatly. I think his feelings regarding the baby’s mother were also genuine.You Were Meant For Me was an interesting book and while I had some reservations about some of the secondary players I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend the novel or pick up another by the same author.Thank you to Penguin Random House for our review copy. All opinions are our own.

I like Lifetime movies. So when I saw the plot of this book, I knew I had to read it.The plot goes like this: Miranda Berenzweig (I had no idea how to pronounce it, so she was just Miranda B in my head) finds an abandoned baby girl. Miranda B decides to adopt the baby girl. She's 35 with no kids of her own and is not in a relationship. This baby might be her only chance to have a kid. Miranda decides to do an interview with a magazine about finding the baby girl. Through this magazine, the father of the baby girl comes forward. He wants the baby. Dun-dun-DUN.It turns out the baby girl's mother was a bit crazy. She wasn't stable. She apparently left her baby and then drowned herself.The father, Jared, thinks he needs to do the right thing and raise the baby. Miranda B named her Celeste. Jared changes it to Lily. (Oh, and sorry if this is a spoiler, but he takes custody in the middle of the book, so it's not a total shocker..) But Jared doesn't think he's cut out to be a father after all, so he wants to give Lily back to Miranda, because he feels like she'll be better off. I mean, I wanted Miranda to be happy, but at the same time, dude, man UP, this is your flesh and blood. Then again, he knows he's not the best parent and he does want what's best for Lily. So Miranda gets Lily back and changes the baby's name BACK to Celeste. The poor kid is probably like "WTF? Who AM I?"Does the custody arrangement stay that way? Read the book and find out.I liked the book, but it seemed to drag on in a few places. I found myself skimming. Maybe because I wanted to know where Celeste/Lily/Celeste was going to end up. If you like Lifetime movies, you'll enjoy this book.

You Were Meant For Me is a fast-paced novel about love – love of a child, a partner, a parent, good friends. The novel starts out with the probable suicide of the baby’s mother. Lucky for the baby, Miranda discovers her on a subway platform and makes sure the baby is taken to the authorities. Over the next few months Miranda steps forward to foster and then adopt the baby. A local writer interviews Miranda for a newspaper column when starts a chain reaction of events that will upend Miranda’s plans and happiness.I thought it was an interesting premise and overall I enjoyed the novel. I liked it but had a tough time with almost every adult character’s self-centeredness at one time or another. Even Miranda dropped the ball a time or two. However, the author brought everything together at the end and I felt a bit better about the growth some of the characters experienced. I especially liked the direction Miranda’s life was headed.This would be a good book to take on vacation. It’s a page turner, has attractive and affluent characters and some romance. I would definitely read more books by the author (this is my first). Included at the end are a Conversation with the Author as well as Discussion Questions.*I received a review copy in exchange for my opinion

I found this book a total pleasure. I began reading it on a Saturday evening and stayed up late to keep in the wonderful company of this story. On Sunday morning I sank back down into it and finished late that day, feeling as if I'd been given a delicious treat of wisdom, savviness, shrewd observation, and profound intimacy. Ms. McDonough conveys the way we register need and desire, the way we build families, the way an inner yearning can surprise someone in its fulfillment.I enjoyed, as well, the way the artistry of the writing. As with other novels by the same author, I felt her incisive knowledge of human nature and of the way the world operates, and I found myself putting stars in the margins at moments that illuminated for me something unexpected and significant about human nature. Her understanding of women's friendships -- their occasionally competitive edge, their ways of healing from ruptures -- also spoke to me. There are certain favorite movies that I watch when I'm blue; I'm grateful to them for captivating me and pulling me into their world. I am grateful to You Were Meant for Me for casting the same compelling spell, and for bringing me so much information about the world and the human heart. I'm not a mother, but this book spoke deeply to me.

Full Review - http://www.dishwaterdreams.com/book-r...You Were Meant for Me is a book about relationships. It seems that every relationship in this book is accidental, which makes it seem quite real. Nothing is forced in the way the characters meet and in the way their relationships evolve.Miranda is the focus of the novel. She is in her mid-thirties, still getting over a bad break-up, and content with her life. Then she finds a baby abandoned in the subway and her whole life changes.Miranda can’t get that baby out of her mind and ends up taking the baby home as her foster mother.Miranda ends up learning a lot about herself with the new journey she accepts and as she learns about the baby she wants to adopt.McDonough’s writing flows smoothly and makes this book an easy but enjoyable read. She really brings you along with the characters as they learn and grow as people. I would highly recommend this as a fantastic beach read this summer!

When you least expect it someone “little” can change the course of your life forever. Author Zona Zeldis McDonough’s You Were Meant For Me was such a joy to read! Right from the start McDonough pulls the reader into the story when Miranda finds an abandoned baby. McDonough does an amazing job conveying the emotional journey Miranda embarks on when she loses her heart to baby “Celeste”. Of course complications arise when Celeste’s biological father turns up but McDonough manages to make all of her characters sympathetic as they experience gut-wrenching choices in this story. McDonough’s characters show us how one tiny baby can turn several people’s lives upside down and force them to grow and learn from their mistakes. In the end, the characters all put the best interests of baby Celeste first. If you’re looking for an emotional read about the true meaning of a mother’s love, a father’s sacrifice and complicated relationships of family and friends then I highly recommend You Were Meant For Me.

[ I wasn't thrilled that he and Miranda ended up together. And Geneva... well, I didn't trust her from the beginning - at least we found out that there was a valid reason not to trust her!  (hide spoiler)]

I really enjoyed this book. It is a very quick read and very difficult to put down. The author does a wonderful job at pulling you into the story from the very beginning. She addresses the strengths and courage of Miranda, who finds a baby and finds the inner strength to do what is best for the child. It certainly makes you think about what you would do in a similar situation. At the same time, the author addresses various relationships and their importance. Throughout the story, the various men have helped shape Miranda into a better person; as a result, she ultimately figures out the more important values in a long-term relationship and grows substantially from what she learns. I highly recommend this book. Thank you for a great read!!

A great story in many ways, with a terrific concept--woman finds abandoned baby on subway platform and decides to raise her. But I had such a negative reaction to Jared, the father of the baby, that when Miranda started making eyes at him I reacted badly to her, too. Certain emotional developments and decisions were skipped over that I think would have been good to hear. Good things: a complex array of secondary characters, a real knock-out of a lead hero.

Intriguing premise, utterly disappointing execution. A perfectly good plot about a woman who finds a newborn on a subway platform is marred by corny dialogue and characters with the emotional maturity of high schoolers. Also, I was frequently distracted by the author's seeming lack of experience with babies. (I know from babies, and I've never met one who was eating solids at 3 months and saying "Mama" at 7 months.)

This one started out interestingly enough, but it didn't take long for me to realize that things were just moving along without anything really interesting happening... small sparks would make me hopeful, and then it would return to the easy, predictable flow of the plot. I soon began to realize that the character development was just lazy, especially relying on stereotypes of gender and class. It became too annoying for me to want to recommend this to anyone else.

DRAMA! Drama drama drama. I got through the first hundred pages and had to take a break. It was just too much. Anyway, it's a pretty good story. A whole lot happened. It's heart-breakingly sad, sweet, frustrating and somewhat happy at the end. The ending was kind of abrupt. It is not a romance in the traditional sense. There is a love story, well two really, but none of it came easy,

Pretty goodLove the plot - finding a baby, drama ensues, etc. The dialogue was a little weird in places - a bit unnatural. Also, Evan was the blandest man ever. I get that he's supposed to be a "nice guy" but nice guys are allowed to have personalities. In fact, most of the characters were pretty dull, as people. But the plot was interesting, and the writing was nice,

Nice story about a lady who finds a baby at a light rail station. Becomes obsesses with welfare of baby, falls in love with her, almost loses her...you know how it goes. Lots of ups and downs and some romance thrown in.

Disappointing book - one of those kind of books that the "synopsis" sounded like it was a great book! I didn't put it away but I stuck through the book wanting it to have a good story.. Didn't happen unfortunately.. I will not be recommending the book .. Not much to say...

Charming story of woman who fins a bay in the subway and her journey to become the abandon baby’s mother. My only complaint is sometime some of the characters felt a little stereotypical but overall a great read.
This had a great premise, poor execution.
I enjoyed this story very much. The main character, Miranda, is not vapid and she has a level head on her shoulders. It was an entertaining story that I enjoyed reading.

description: What do you do when you have to give up the person you love most? Thirty-five-year-old Miranda is not an impulsive person. She’s been at Domestic Goddess magazine for eight years, she has great friends, and she’s finally moving on after a breakup. Having a baby isn’t even on her radar—until the day she discovers an abandoned newborn on the platform of a Brooklyn subway station. Rushing the little girl to the closest police station, Miranda hopes and prays she’ll be all right and that a loving family will step forward to take her. Yet Miranda can’t seem to get the baby off her mind and keeps coming up with excuses to go check on her, until finally a family court judge asks whether she’d like to be the baby’s foster parent—maybe even adopt her. To her own surprise, Miranda jumps at the chance. But nothing could have prepared her for the ecstasy of new-mother love—or the heartbreak she faces when the baby’s father surfaces.... CONVERSATION GUIDE INCLUDED
title: You Were Meant for Me
